did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: Hoover Institution on War, Revolution, and Peace

did.abstract: Writings, correspondence, card files, and printed matter, relating to economics, anti-communist movements, and Russian émigré affairs. Includes records of the Koordinatsionnyi TSentr Antibol'shevistskoi Bor'by and some papers of Aleksandr Kerensky.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

chronitem.event: Officer in the Russian Imperial Army during World War I and served with the anti-Bolshevik forces under Admiral Kolchak in Siberia. Captured by the Red Army, imprisoned and eventually released
Lectured at the Leningrad Financial-Economic Institute
Held chair at the Institute of Soviet Cooperative Trade in Moscow
Evacuated from Leningrad with the Financial-Economic Institute to the North Caucasus
Held a leading position and presided over the Coordinating Center of Anti-Bolshevik Struggle
Author, Reformizm v SSSR, Sel'skoe khoziaistvo na novom etape, Sovremennoe polozhenie vlasti v SSSR
Author, Natsii SSSR i russkii vopros

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Ivan Alekseevich Kurganov, acquired in 2001, consist of correspondence, published and unpublished writings, including manuscripts of books and articles, reports, and memoranda. These materials document the political and intellectual life of Professor Kurganov and his contemporaries from the early 1950s through the late 1970s. Kurganov's associates included well-known Russian émigrés such as Sergei P. Mel'gunov, Mikhail Karpovich, V. Orekhov, Vladmir Samarin, and many others. The most important correspondent was Alexander Kerensky.

After World War II, Kurganov worked as a journalist for the Russian émigré press. His work as a journalist is reflected in the speeches and writings series. Between the years 1959 and 1980 Professor Kurganov published several books, and many articles and pamphlets, also included in the series.

Included in the Kurganov collection are the records of the Coordinating Center of Anti-Bolshevik Struggle (Munich), which sought to unify the political activities of various anti-Soviet Russian émigré organizations. From 1951 to 1956, Professor Kurganov held a leading position in and later presided over the Center. During this time, he worked closely with Alexander Kerensky and Sergei P. Mel'gunov. The records of the Coordinating Center provide a wealth of information on anti-Soviet activities in the Russian émigré community during the 1950s. Of great interest are Alexander Kerensky's letters on his anti-Soviet political activities, relations with a new generation of Russian émigrés (displaced persons), and his stance on many other issues.

scopecontent.p: Certificates, curriculum vitae, books, identification cards, immigration documents, and other materials relating to the life and career of I. A. Kurganov
Letters to and from various individuals and organizations. Arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent
Book manuscripts, essays, reports, studies, speeches, and other writings by I. A. Kurganov. Arranged chronologically by title

did.unittitle: Koordinatsionnyi Tsentr Anti-Bol'shevistskoi Bor'by (Coordinating Center of Anti-Bolshevik Struggle), 1948-1980.

scopecontent.p: Announcement, clippings, correspondence, reports, and subject file relating to the activities of the Koordinatsionnyi Tsentr, collected by I. A. Kurganov. Arranged alphabetically by physical form
Typescripts and printed copies of writings by authors associated with I. A. Kurganov. Arranged alphabetically by name of author

Clippings from various newspapers, serials, and other printed publications, relating to events and conditions in the Soviet Union, the Russian emigration in Europe and the United States, collected by I. A. Kurganov for his research. Arranged alphabetically by subject
Reference cards to sources relating to a variety of subjects used by I. A. Kurganov for his research
